quote: Another Coco-no-no?
No thanks, I think I've had enough   already.
Yeah, me too.
Geordi...
What?
I'm sorry. I think I better go   back now.
You're chilly... ? I can turn down   the breeze...
No, it's been a lovely program,   and you're a terrific guy...
Yeah...
I just don't feel that way about   you...
Yeah...
Knock it off.
Do you require full termination   of the Holodeck program or just   the audio portion?
This was the final battle, wasn't   it?
Neither side intended Orelious   Nine to be the decisive conflict.
Not much of it left, is there...
The destruction is remarkable   considering the primitive weapons   of the period.
Uh oh...
I beg your pardon, Wesley?
"Uh oh"... it's an expression,   Data. It just means, you know,   uh oh, something's wrong...
There is something wrong?
Commander La Forge had a big date   with Christy tonight. He's been   working on the perfect program   for days. Looks like it ended   kinda early.
Uh oh.
Commander Data to the bridge   immediately.
Acknowledged.
We're picking up a signal,   coordinates two-one-one mark   six-one.
It is an ancient interplanetary   code.
Survivors on Orelious Nine after   all this time... not possible.
Not at all possible. Lay in a   course to the source of the   signal.
Approaching the source, Captain...
Put it on the viewer, Mister Data.
A Promellian battle cruiser.
And with its Lang Cycle fusion   engines intact.
Scanners indicate no life signs   aboard.
I should hope not. That ship   belongs in a museum.       Gentlemen, I'm afraid we're a   little late. This call for help   was very likely initiated over   a thousand years ago.

Captain's log, Stardate 43799.1.   We have arrived at Orelious Nine,   to chart the battle in which the   Menthars and Promellians fought   to their mutual extinction. Among   the ruins we have found a relic:   a Promellian battle cruiser that   has withstood the centuries.
scene: 14   EXT. SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE AND THE ANCIENT WARSHIP

quote: Indulge me, Number One...
I'd prefer Lieutenant Worf and   I did a security sweep of the   vessel first...
No. Captain's prerogative, here.   This one's mine. We've examined   every conceivable risk...
The risks aboard a vessel this   old and fragile are inconceivable,   Captain...
Ghosts, perhaps?       Haven't you ever dreamed of   climbing inside the bottle... ?
Sir... ?
The ship in the bottle, Number   One. Model air ships... I used   to build them as a child. By God,   I'll bet I even had a Promellian   battle cruiser too.
Ready to beam the away team to   the vessel...
Locked on to the Main Bridge,   Captain...
You're certain about the   atmospheric conditions, Data... ?
There is adequate oxygen for life   support, Commander...
It is exactly as they left it,   Number One. In the bottle.       Good Lord, didn't anyone else here   build ships in bottles when they   were boys?
I did not play with toys.
I was never a boy.
(speaking up, filling     the breach)   I did, sir.
Thank you, Mister O'Brien.   Proceed.
I did. I really did. Ships in   bottles. Great fun.
What's that?
Not sure. The secondary power   bus may need adjusting.
Let me know.

Extraordinary. You would expect   the layout of a bridge from this   era to be clumsy, awkward... but   see this -- it is a model of   simplicity. They built the same   craft for generations. And it   worked.
Admirable. They died at their   posts.
Don't you have anything stronger   than this, Guinan?
Yes.
Would it help?
No.
Can you tell me something, Guinan?   You're a woman, right?
Yes, I can tell you that.
What is it that... you want in   a man?
Me personally?
As a woman. What's the first   thing you look at?
His head.
Uh huh... his mind, of course.
No, his head. I'm attracted to   bald men.
Seriously?
Seriously.
Why?
Maybe because a bald man was very   kind to me once... when I was   hurting. Took care of me.
I'd like to do that.
I'm taking care of myself these   days.

I mean take care of somebody.       Guinan, I just don't get it...   I can field strip a fusion   reactor... I can realign a power   transfer tunnel... why can't I   make anything work with a woman   like Christy? I don't know what   to do, what to say...
I never noticed... as a woman.
You're different.
No, you're different.
But I'm not trying now.
Exactly.
The source of the distress signal   is twenty meters ahead...
Mister Worf, be sure we get   tricorder images of their tactical   display...
Yes, sir.
Look here, Worf... how well laid   out it is. We went through how   many different designs before   we reached this kind of   sophistication... ?

I believe it was four, sir. We   did not have a fully integrated   tactical command until the   twenty-third century. In fact,   several of the Promellian   innovations served as inspiration   for early Federation starship   design...
As well they should have.
Positron ducts. These channeled   power from one end of the ship   to the other.
It is safe to enter.
Let's put an end to their last   cry for help.
Captain...
I believe this is an information   storage device... a crude analogue   of our own iso-linear optical   chip.

Crude by our standards today,   Data. When this ship was built,   humans on Earth had just perfected   the mechanical clock... and were   using steel crossbows in battle.       Is there any way to see what's   on this?
Questionable. I can supply power   to the playback unit, Captain...   but the components are quite   old... I will attempt to amplify   its image with a tricorder...
What is it, Wes?
The main power return is acting   a little weird...
Define "weird".
I'm getting fluctuating waveguide   readings...
Run a maintenance sweep.
Right.
I am Galek Sar, Captain of the   Promellian cruiser, Cleponji.   I wish anyone who finds this   record to know my crew has behaved   courageously.
I want it recorded for all time   that I, alone, am responsible for   the fate that befell us.       I have failed -- as a captain.   And as the man responsible for   all the souls aboard my ship.
Indeed, sir.       Picard to Enterprise.
Go ahead, Captain.
I think we've seen just about all   there is to see here. At Mister   O'Brien's convenience... we are   ready to return...
Aye, sir.
You were absolutely right, Number   One. There were ghosts aboard   the old ship after all... one of   them even spoke to us.
A friendly one, I hope.
My own counterpart. The ship   captain's final message...   praising his crew.
I hope you'll be as thoughtful   when the time comes.
Data, advise the Astral-Five annex   of the Smithsonian... This should   be catalogued and scheduled for   retrieval...
I'm sorry... it's just a rare   pleasure to meet this side of your   personality, Captain.
Mister Crusher, set our course   for the original coordinates.
Yessir.
Captain, we are experiencing a two   percent drop in our energy   reserves. Compensating.
We were having a few problems   while...
Readouts indicate we are being   bombarded with a field of high   intensity radiation.
Shields up.
Captain, energy loss increasing   to five percent. I am unable to   correct.
Yellow Alert.
Maybe I should've gone with the   Mardi Gras program... something   a little livelier...
You ever consider doing it   without a program?
You're a pilot... Try flying   without instruments for a   change... you might surprise   yourself.
Mister La Forge, report to   Engineering...
On my way, Commander.
Save my seat, Guinan.
Always room at the bar for another   broken heart.
Energy loss increasing.
Mister Crusher, reverse course.   Full impulse power.
Sir, there's no response.
Increase speed to warp one.
Engines are not responding, sir.
Mister La Forge, I need warp power   now!

Matter/anti-matter mixture ratio   settings at optimum balance...   Reaction sequence corresponding   to specified norms... Magnetic   plasma transfer to warp field   generators per program specs.   Commander, we should be going   like a bat out of hell.
Power loss now at twelve percent.
Red Alert.
Radiation intensity increasing.
We better slow these engines down   before we burn out the reaction   chamber.
Slow to idle, Geordi.
Is it possible... have we stumbled   into the same snare that killed   them? A thousand-year-old...   booby trap?
With the engines idling, the   energy loss has been limited.   But our reserves will be depleted   in less than three hours. We   won't be able to hold our shields   in place.
If we lose shields, the radiation   will kill everyone on board,   Captain.
Not everyone, Doctor.
I stand corrected.
Have you identified the source   of the radiation, Mister Worf?
No, sir. The radiation field is   too strong -- it interferes with   our sensors.
And no apparent explanation for   the loss of energy... ?
Anything in the history books,   Data that might give us a clue... ?

There are many fascinating records   of Menthar battle strategy...   they were exceptionally   innovative. In fact, they were   the first to devise the Kavis Teke   elusive maneuver as well as a   Passive Lure stratagem that is   comparable to Napoleon's...
Any mention of a situation like   this?
No.
Recommend I lead an away team to   the cruiser.
They didn't have much success with   this problem, Commander...
But at least they knew their enemy   better than we do. Maybe they   even knew how they got into   trouble... they just didn't know   how to get out.
Agreed. Worf, what would be the   impact of lowering shields long   enough to get an away team out... ?
Negligible, sir.
It won't help our energy   conservation any, Captain.
That's your job, Commander La   Forge. Determine a way to keep   the Enterprise up and running.   Data, you will join Commander   Riker on the away team. Find out   what happened to that ship.
Radiation factor is within safe   human limits, Commander.
Why isn't this ship being hit with   radiation?
That is curious, Commander. The   radiation field must be   directional in nature... aimed   only at the Enterprise.
Maybe our own engines triggered   it somehow...       Data, see if you can determine   what kind of defenses the   Promellians tried to employ...   I don't want to waste time trying   them again...
Understood.
What'd really help us is a ship's   log... any kind of record of their   last battle.
So why can't we move?
Computer, as we increased our   power levels, was there any   counter-reaction?
Affirmative. The opposing force   grew in direct proportion to the   power output of the Enterprise.
So it kept us from forming a   subspace field for the warp drive?
That is correct.
Computer, who is this L. Brahms?
Doctor Leah Brahms. Engineer.   Graduate of the Daystrom   Institute. Theoretical Propulsion   Group, Galaxy class starships.   Team seven, junior member.
Junior member, huh. Looks like   she wrote the book on propulsion.       Call up subspace design logs...
Select menu, visual records or   L. Brahms' voice entries.
Voice entries.
Theoretical propulsion logs,   Federation Starship Enterprise,   Galaxy class. Heading: Subspace.   Author: Leah Brahms.
Geordi La Forge. How ya doin,   Doc...
Yeah, down to work. You're   absolutely right.
I recommend we evacuate and seal   off all non-operational areas and   group the families and crew on   odd-numbered decks.
Proceed.
I'd also like to set up an   assembly area for treating   radiation in case we need it.
After the shields fall, how long   for a fatal exposure?
Thirty minutes. After that,   there's nothing that can be done.
Away team to bridge. Captain, we   may have found something...
We're in the Promellian   communications area...

quote: That's what we were thinking.

quote: Data, are the coils in working   condition?

quote: Good. Return at once.

quote: What about the dilithium crystal   control?
It should be possible to fine tune   the frequency ranges...
Yes?
And the propulsion group is   investigating numerous theories   to determine how.
Great. Thanks a lot. Computer,   generate a cross section image   of the dilithium crystal chamber.
What about reorienting the   crystal?
It is possible to reorient the   crystal. The key lies in   adjusting the lattice structure   direction. This modification will   be integrated into the next class   starship.
Sorry, can't wait. You and me,   Leah. We have two hours to figure   this out.
You know what I need to do -- I   need to get inside there. I need   to turn that thing inside out...       Computer, is there a cross section   of the engines we can replicate   on a Holodeck?
Select menu: design specifications   or prototype schematic.
Prototype? Elaborate...
A development stage prototype   schematic at Utopia Planitia,   drafting room five, of the Mars   Station, Stardate 40174.
Perfect. Recreate it in Holodeck   Three. Stay with me, Doc.
Ready computer?
Holodeck Three program is ready.
Damn. Right back where it all   started. This is incredible...
Leah, did you design this?
The dilithium crystal chamber was   designed at outpost designated   Seran-T-one, Stardate 40052...   Some of the Federation's best   engineering minds participated   in its development.
Sure, that's visiting dignitary   talk, what's the inside story...   off-the-record?
Access denied. Personal logs are   restricted.
Another woman who won't get   personal with me in the Holodeck.
Leah, I want to find a way to   supplement the energy supply to   the ship and to the engines.   Could we alter the matter/anti-matter   paths?
Theoretically, yes. The system   should be able to accept more   reactants at a faster rate of   injection.
Well, this is your baby, show me   which ones...
Computer, did I ask for a   simulation?
Affirmative. You asked Doctor   Brahms to show you which system   could accept reactants at a faster   rate. By accessing available   imagery, an adequate facsimile   was possible.
I did do that, didn't I?
Okay... Leah... good to see you...
Real good.
Continue your analysis.
Systems L-452 through L-575 will   accept reactants, providing all   other systems are calibrated to   an equal factor.
Then, if we use multiple injector   streams, hitting more than one   crystal facet, we could do it...   we could hold our own. Leah,   you're beautiful.       La Forge to Picard....
Go ahead.
scene: 45   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE AND TWO (OPTICAL))
location: MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE AND TWO

quote: Captain, we've found a way to   extend the matter/anti-matter   energy supplies.
scene: 45   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE AND TWO (OPTICAL))
location: MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE AND TWO

quote: Well done, Mister La Forge.
scene: 45   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE AND TWO (OPTICAL))
location: MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE AND TWO

quote: Geordi, can you give us enough   energy to get us out of here?
scene: 45   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE AND TWO (OPTICAL))
location: MAIN BRIDGE - SCIENCE ONE AND TWO

quote: Sorry, Commander... we haven't   addressed that one yet. First   priority was to maintain shields.
Acknowledged.
We'll get on it, right away,   though...
Pass on my congratulations to your   team, Commander.
Thanks, Captain. We're... all   smiles down here.
Picard out.
We have been able to verify that   these coils are logs of the   Promellian captain... but most   of them have decayed and cannot   be repaired...
They're beyond any sort of   playback... ?
On most there are brief sections   that may yield some information.
Do the best you can, Data. Let's   just hope we have the brief   section we need...
He must have logged the cause of   his ship's death. What captain   wouldn't?
They were all in an open locker.   I don't think he was too concerned   with security.
... 452 through system L-575.
Adjustments to dilithium crystal   chamber complete.
Impact analysis, computer.
Warp energy has increased fourteen   percent. Reactants per unit time   remaining steady.
All right.
Computer, do you have any... you   know... personality... on file   for Doctor Brahms?
Starfleet personality profile   analysis, stardate 37650...
Did she ever debate at the   intergalactic caucuses on   Chaya-seven?
Doctor Brahms attended Chaya-seven   caucuses on the following   stardates...
Never mind the dates...       Computer, if you add all data   from these sources, could you   synthesize a true representation   of Doctor Brahms?
There would be a nine-point-three   percent margin of error in the   interactive responses from the   facsimile.
I can live with that. Make it   happen.
Doctor Brahms?
Geordi, it's me, Leah. Don't   start calling me "Doctor Brahms"   or I'll call you "Commander" La   Forge.
Right.
Now, we've managed to maintain   energy but we can't leave it in   this realignment forever without   burning out components so we need   to move quickly...
Are you with me?
Right.

... have been stripped of all   propulsion, and our weapons are   useless. We can't move -- and   we can't fight. The ship is being   lashed with lethal radiation from   the Aceton assimilators concealed   in the rubble surrounding....
scene: 49   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Aceton assimilators -- ?
scene: 49   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: An Aceton assimilator is a   primitive generator which can   drain power from distant sources.
scene: 49   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Generator...
scene: 49   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: It would not be difficult to   modify them to convert energy into   radiation.
scene: 49   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: The Menthars hide them in the   floating debris... and an   unsuspecting enemy ship flies   in... instant booby trap.
scene: 49   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: And now we're supplying the   devices with the energy to kill   us.
scene: 49   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: No... no... no...
Will you listen to me...
You can't boost the warp power   that way...
If you can just increase the speed   of the parallel subspace field   processor to gain a quicker   response time...
I want to give us enough power   to strengthen the shields and   barrel out of here... not blow   us up...
This is my design we're talking   about. I did all the calculations   myself.
I don't care if you built it with   your bare hands out of an old   Ferengi cargo ship, it's going   to go --
-- and we're going with it.
I'm not used to having people   question my judgment.
And I'm not used to dying.       You worked in a lab on a static   model. This is a working machine,   it has tens of thousands of   light years on it.
True.
Damn right.       We'd never be certain the circuit   paths are sealed.
You're good. Very good.
I know my ship. Inside and out.
Then I guess you know me. Inside   and out. Cause a lot of me is   in here.
I always wished the chief engineer   could be present when a ship is   being built.
And that's what's wrong with   designers -- we never get out in   space.
You're there now.
Commander La Forge to the bridge.
On my way, Commander.       Don't go anywhere.       I mean, computer -- save program.
How many of these devices do we   think we're dealing with?
To create the radiation field we   are experiencing, it would take   several hundred thousand, Captain...
They've been out there a long   time, Data... there must be some   deterioration....
There is no way to calculate that   precisely, Commander... but it   is likely...
Is there any indication of a   weakness in a specific part of   the field...
Nothing substantial, Captain.
Of any kind.
A point-one percent dip in the   strength of the radiation field   at two-one mark eight by   four-two mark zero...
I'll take that point-one percent.
Recommend we fire a directional   phaser pattern at those   coordinates...
We won't be able to maintain   energy reserves... we might even   lose some circuits in the new   configuration...
How critical would the losses be?
Not enough to shut down our   engines... but if we don't make   it... I don't know if we could   hold shields.
There is also the possibility the   phasers will supply the   assimilators with what they need   most -- energy.
Mister La Forge, alternative   suggestions?
Maybe down the road, Captain...   But we can't overload the   dilithium crystals much longer.

I imagine a discussion very much   like this took place on our   neighbor's ship a thousand years   ago. May our decisions meet with   more success than theirs.       Mister La Forge, you will return   to Engineering and continue your   efforts without delay. Mister   Worf, prepare the phasers.
Phasers locked on coordinates.
Fire.
Nothing.
Radiation levels increasing,   Captain. Eight percent. Ten   percent.
Energy reserves on board dropping   rapidly...
Damn you.
Wouldn't that increase the output   of the parallel subspace   processors to gain a quicker   response time... ?
The processors can handle the   extra input.
Yeah, but how do we   reconfigure... ?
Energy reserves reaching critical   stage. Standard procedure   requires termination of all   simulations.
Computer, override standard   procedure...
Override authority restricted.
What? -- computer --
The crystal lattice is breaking   down...
We'll have to pick up repairs when   we can reach a starbase....
The optimist in the group.
How long do we have shields based   on current calculations... ?
Under two hours, Captain. And   the radiation field has   increased by seventeen percent.
Impact on fatal exposure?
Down to twenty-six minutes.
If we resist, we die. If we don't   resist, we die.
Mister La Forge, have we shut down   all non-essential energy usage?
Yes, Captain. In fact, I need   to get some back... I'm running   a program on Holodeck Three...
For what purpose?
I've gone back to the beginning...   to the earliest construction   entries of the Enterprise. I've   created... a... propulsion design   model to assist me. I believe   we're... making progress...
Computer, reinstate Holodeck Three   program.
Holodeck Three program is   reinstated.
Your best suggestion in an hour,   Mister La Forge. Picard out.
Computer, resume Holodeck Three   program.
Enter when ready.
There isn't much time left.
Somehow, we have to generate   enough energy to get out of   here... but we've got a   booby-trap that eats energy for   breakfast... how do we fool it,   block it, shut it down,   anything...
Okay, we know for every movement   the Enterprise makes, there's a   counter-movement from the energy   field... could we use that to our   advantage somehow...
Maybe. There must be a time   differential between the force   and counter-force response...
If we could make quick, continuing   adjustments in the linkups before   the counterforce reacts, we might   just be able to move this   bucket...
Yes...
Leah, you like Italian food?
Like it? Wait til I make you my   fungilli.
Okay, fusion reactor uplink to   navigation processor...
But then we have to adjust the   drive coils... and the vector   processor... it's impossible..

quote: Don't do that...
scene: 61   INT. HOLODECK/DRAFTING ROOM - ON SCREEN DISPLAY

quote: Sorry... I thought it might feel   good.
scene: 61   INT. HOLODECK/DRAFTING ROOM - ON SCREEN DISPLAY

quote: I don't want to feel that good   right now. What time is it?
scene: 61   INT. HOLODECK/DRAFTING ROOM - ON SCREEN DISPLAY

quote: Coming up on sixteen hundred   hours.
scene: 61   INT. HOLODECK/DRAFTING ROOM - ON SCREEN DISPLAY

quote: God, what am I supposed to tell   the Captain?
scene: 61   INT. HOLODECK/DRAFTING ROOM - ON SCREEN DISPLAY

quote: It's possible and yet it's   impossible... everything we've   done says we can't adjust fast   enough... but if we could, it   might work...
scene: 61   INT. HOLODECK/DRAFTING ROOM - ON SCREEN DISPLAY

quote: I could do it.
scene: 61   INT. HOLODECK/DRAFTING ROOM - ON SCREEN DISPLAY

quote: Data couldn't even do it. It'll   take a hundred... maybe even a   thousand adjustments every   second... how are you gonna do   it? It's humanly impossible.

quote: I'm not human.

quote: We... I've been examining the   force and counter-force response   time... and trying to see if we   could create linkage at maximum   power...

quote: The bottom line, Commander.
scene: 61   INT. HOLODECK/DRAFTING ROOM - ON SCREEN DISPLAY

quote: What kind of chance?

quote: Proceed.

quote: This is the only way...

quote: I think so, Captain.

quote: Come.
Any word from La Forge?
He's come up with something that   might give us a chance. If we   agree to stay out of it.
Sir?
He proposes to turn control of   the ship over to the computer   because it is capable of making   quicker adjustments than any human   being.
Computers have always impressed   me by their ability to take   orders; I'm not at all as certain   about their ability to give them.
Especially with a thousand lives   at stake.       What choice do I have?

You missed something by not   playing with model ships. They   were the source of one boy's   imaginary voyages, each holding   a treasure of adventures. Manning   the earliest space craft. Or   flying a plane with only one   propeller to keep you in the sky.   Imagine that.       Now, the machines are flying us.
Fatal radiation exposure.
Computer, reduce thrust levels   another four percent... adjust   trajectory angle to compensate...   begin simulation again...
There you go. We got out.
Repeat simulation, same levels.
Fatal radiation exposure.
Swell. Same variables. Only   this time the computer didn't   quite make it...
Deflector shield failure. Lethal   radiation levels. Fatal exposure   in twenty-six minutes.
Deflector shield failure. Lethal   radiation levels. Fatal exposure   in twenty-three minutes.
I can't do it.
It might work, Geordi.
And it might not. I can't   ask the captain to turn the ship   over to a computer.
It's all we've got.
Picard to La Forge.
Captain... two minutes... give   me just two minutes....
There is another way, Captain...   two minutes...
Two minutes. Picard out.
Geordi, there's no other way...
No..no... wait, listen... turn   it upside down, literally... come   at it from the opposite   direction... God, it's so   simple... it might even work...
Lethal levels of radiation...
Computer, shut up... at least in   Holodeck Three...
Computer, new simulation...

Everything we've been trying to   do is based on overpowering the   trap... more energy, faster   adjustments... but that's exactly   what we can't do, because that's   what we're supposed to do. That's   the booby trap.       The answer is in our own   computer... the mind -- the best   piece of engineering we'll ever   need.
Didn't your research suggest   thousands of adjustments would   be required per second?
Not if we turn everything off.
One blast of everything we've got   left for a microsecond to beat   the inertia and then we shut it   all down except minimal life   support and two thrusters. No   impulse engines. No computer.
One propeller, Captain...
Deflector shield failure. Lethal   radiation levels. Fatal exposure   in twelve minutes.
Have you analyzed the risk factor?

The numbers say it's even money.   No better than handing it over to   the computer. No worse either.   But I say forget the numbers.   There's no way for a computer to   compensate for the human factor...   the intuition, the experience...
Make it ready.
I've run the simulations... If   you want me to take Conn...
No, Mister La Forge. You've done   your job. Now I must do mine.
I relieve you, Mister Crusher.
Yes, sir.

All hands, this is Commander   Riker. We are about to engage   impulse engines for a short burst.   Inertial dampers are on manual.   They may not fully compensate for   acceleration. Brace yourselves.
Deflector shield failure. Lethal   radiation levels. Fatal --
Computer, discontinue radiation   warning till further notice.
Firing impulse engines.
Impulse engines are now down.
Shutting down all systems.
Velocity is one hundred thirty   two meters per second.
We will enter the debris field   in eight seconds.
Starboard thruster firing.
Coming to heading three-four-zero   mark one-zero.
Captain, that large mass to port   may contain an assimilator.
Port thruster firing...
No reaction from the assimilator.
We're past the first hurdle.
Sir! Object to port --
Starboard thruster.
Sir, the gravitational attraction   of the various masses has reduced   our velocity by eight percent.   By my calculations, we no longer   possess sufficient momentum to   clear the debris field --
Thank you, Mister Data.
Port thruster...
The asteroid's gravity is drawing   us closer. Velocity increasing.
Velocity still increasing... now   two hundred and nineteen meters   per second.
Starboard thruster.
You have used the asteroid's   gravitational pull as a   slingshot. Excellent.
We're out. We beat it.
Mister Crusher, the conn is yours.
Yes, sir!
Initiate full restart. Bring all   systems back on-line.
With pleasure, sir.
Number One... make sure the booby   trap won't bother anyone again.
Mister Worf, ready photon   torpedoes, all bays... set to   detonate upon impact with the   Promellian vessel.
Aye, sir.

I've always thought that   technology could solve any   problem. It enhances our quality   of life... It lets us travel   across the galaxy... It even gave   me my vision.       But sometimes you just need to   trust yourself and turn it all   off. Even the gypsy violins.
Violins?
Different program. Sorry.
We made a good team.
Maybe we could do it again some   time.
I'm with you every day, Geordi.   Every time you look at this   engine, you're looking at me.   Every time you touch it, it's me.
Computer, exit Holodeck. Save   program.
